front.title: Problem Statement for Special-Use Domain Names

abstract.t: The dominant protocol for name resolution on the Internet is the Domain Name System (DNS). However, other protocols exist that are fundamentally different from the DNS, but which have syntactically-similar namespaces.

When an end-user triggers resolution of a name on a system which supports multiple, different protocols for name resolution, it is desirable that the protocol to be used is unambiguous, and that requests intended for one protocol are not inadvertently addressed using another.

RFC 6761 introduced a framework by which, under certain circumstances, a reservation could be made to accommodate non-DNS name resolution protocols and avoid the possibility of collisions between the two different, but syntactically-similar namespaces.

Various challenges have become apparent with the application of the guidance provided in RFC 6761 to real world protocols and namespaces. This document aims to document those challenges in the form of a problem statement, to facilitate discussion of future improvements to RFC 6761.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document aims to document a problem statement that will inform future work, and hence presents no implications for Internet security.
